texts.shortText: Test hemispherical to fairly conical (taller than most regional species), pale grey to cream with paler radial bands where the tube feet occur (ambulacra). Areas between the bands of tube feet (interambulacra) with sparsely-distributed large tubercles (to which primary spines attach) and many more much smaller ones. Live animal with sparse white primary spines, each about 25% test diameter and dense mats of much smaller, darker secondary spines between.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about East London.

Not found intertidally and rarely extends inshore to depths as shallow as 10 m, where it is sometimes seen by divers. Becomes much more common in deeper waters, where it is frequently recorded in trawled samples.
Not known and most commonly found in depths devoid of algae, so probably feeds on organic debris.

Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Like almost all urchins a broadcast spawner with planktonic larvae, but details of reproductive cycle not known for this species.

Can co-occur and be confused with the Cape urchin, which occurs over much the same range, but mostly in shallower waters. However that species has a green test and live animals are usually bright red or purple (but sometimes pale) and have much more dense cover of more equal-length spines.
